oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Body Temperature and White Blood Cell Count in Dairy Cows During the First Ten Days After Calving
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Wagner, S. A.
Schimek, D. E.
Cheng, F. C.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: postpartum period
physiological stress
rectal temperature
white blood cell counts
immune
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The postpartum period is a time of physiological stress for high-producing dairy cows. Close monitoring of recently calved cows enables the earliest possible intervention when illness develops. An objective of this study was to evaluate the use of rectal temperature as a diagnostic tool in postpartum cows. As immune suppression is common in postpartum dairy cows, another objective was to compare white blood cell counts in the postpartum period between cows that developed clinical disease and those that did not.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 2007; 233
